# ANSI Terminal Code Generator

## Overview

This Python module generates ANSI escape sequences for terminal text formatting and cursor control. It provides a convenient way to add colors, styling, and cursor manipulation to terminal applications without having to remember the underlying ANSI escape codes.

## Purpose

The module serves as a utility library for:
- Applying foreground and background colors to terminal text
- Adding text styling (bright, dim, normal)
- Controlling cursor movement and positioning
- Clearing screen and line content
- Setting terminal window titles

## Constants

The module defines several key ANSI escape sequence prefixes:

```python
CSI = '\033['  # Control Sequence Introducer
OSC = '\033]'  # Operating System Command
BEL = '\a'     # Bell character
```

## Core Functions

### `code_to_chars(code)`
Converts a numeric ANSI code to a properly formatted escape sequence.

**Parameters:**
- `code`: Numeric ANSI code

**Returns:** String in format `\033[{code}m`

### `set_title(title)`
Generates escape sequence to set the terminal window title.

**Parameters:**
- `title`: String to set as window title

**Returns:** OSC escape sequence for title setting

### `clear_screen(mode=2)`
Generates escape sequence to clear the terminal screen.

**Parameters:**
- `mode`: Clear mode (default=2, entire screen)
  - `0`: Clear from cursor to end of screen
  - `1`: Clear from cursor to beginning of screen  
  - `2`: Clear entire screen

### `clear_line(mode=2)`
Generates escape sequence to clear terminal line content.

**Parameters:**
- `mode`: Clear mode (default=2, entire line)
  - `0`: Clear from cursor to end of line
  - `1`: Clear from cursor to beginning of line
  - `2`: Clear entire line

## Classes

### `AnsiCodes`
Base class that automatically converts numeric ANSI codes to escape sequences upon instantiation.

**Behavior:**
- Scans class attributes for numeric codes
- Converts them to formatted escape sequences using `code_to_chars()`
- Sets instance attributes with the converted sequences

### `AnsiCursor`
Provides cursor movement and positioning methods.

**Methods:**
- `UP(n=1)`: Move cursor up n lines
- `DOWN(n=1)`: Move cursor down n lines  
- `FORWARD(n=1)`: Move cursor forward n columns
- `BACK(n=1)`: Move cursor back n columns
- `POS(x=1, y=1)`: Position cursor at coordinates (x, y)

### `AnsiFore`
Defines foreground (text) color codes.

**Standard Colors:**
- `BLACK`, `RED`, `GREEN`, `YELLOW`, `BLUE`, `MAGENTA`, `CYAN`, `WHITE`
- `RESET`: Reset to default foreground color

**Extended Colors (non-standard but widely supported):**
- `LIGHTBLACK_EX`, `LIGHTRED_EX`, `LIGHTGREEN_EX`, etc.

### `AnsiBack`
Defines background color codes with the same color options as `AnsiFore`.

### `AnsiStyle`
Defines text styling options.

**Available Styles:**
- `BRIGHT`: Bold/bright text
- `DIM`: Dimmed text
- `NORMAL`: Normal intensity
- `RESET_ALL`: Reset all formatting

## Global Instances

The module provides pre-instantiated objects for immediate use:

```python
Fore   = AnsiFore()    # Foreground colors
Back   = AnsiBack()    # Background colors  
Style  = AnsiStyle()   # Text styling
Cursor = AnsiCursor()  # Cursor control
```

## Usage Example

```python
# Print colored text
print(Fore.RED + "This is red text" + Style.RESET_ALL)
print(Back.YELLOW + Fore.BLACK + "Black text on yellow background" + Style.RESET_ALL)

# Move cursor and clear screen
print(Cursor.UP(3) + Cursor.FORWARD(10) + "Positioned text")
print(clear_screen())
```

## Notes and Considerations

- **Compatibility**: ANSI escape sequences work on most Unix-like terminals and modern Windows terminals
- **Extended Colors**: Light color variants (`*_EX`) are widely supported but not part of the official ANSI standard
- **Reset Important**: Always use `Style.RESET_ALL` or appropriate reset codes to avoid formatting bleeding into subsequent output
- **Terminal Support**: Some older or minimal terminals may not support all codes

## Dependencies

This module has no external dependencies and uses only Python standard library features.
